body:
According to:
[https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime#binaries](url)
[https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/blob/master/BUILD.md#linuxmac-os-x](url)
You shall install from Nuget(s)
I think you want `--build_shared_lib` to make the so file you can link against.

@liqunfu Correct me if I'm wrong, but isn't nuget Windows-only? Besides, according to your first link (which is broken btw), the prebuilt libraries are built against CUDA 10.1. I would prefer CUDA 10.0.

@Craigacp No, I don't want shared libs. I want .a files which are static libs. I'm in fact surprised that `make install` came up with .so files although I did not specify `--build_shared_lib`.
Nuget isn't Windows-only.  You can also get a prebuilt binary in tarball format from https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/releases/tag/v1.4.0

@jf99 you may build onnxruntime with Cuda 10.0 (seems you already did). The shared library (libonnxruntime.so) is installed so it can be loaded at runtime. If you prefer tighter integration with onnxruntime, you may choose to fork onnxruntion and add your project into it. That is one way you make use of libonnxruntime_*.a. You may take a look at how onnx_test_runner is built within the repo.

BTW, libonnxruntime.so is not built if you did not specify --build_shared_lib (at least it was not on my Ubuntu machine)

This issue has been automatically marked as stale due to inactivity and will be closed in 7 days if no further activity occurs. If further support is needed, please provide an update and/or more details.
This issue has been automatically closed due to inactivity. Please reactivate if further support is needed.

The copy_strip_binary.sh is used by onnxruntime CI to generate the prebuilt Linux packages and publish it [here](https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/releases/), so instead of running make install, we can run 
`tools/ci_build/github/linux/copy_strip_binary.sh -r build/Linux -a onnxruntime -l libonnxruntime.so.1.9.1 -c RelWithDebInfo -s . -t 2a96b73a1afa9aaafb51`

The scripts generates onnxruntime diretory under build/Linux, we can copy it to the place we want to install the library.
`cp -r build/Linux/onnxruntime/ ~/install/`

issue.title: How to install a custom build of onnxruntime with CUDA as execution provider?

labels.name: build
labels.description: build issues; typically submitted using template

labels.name: platform:windows
labels.description: issues related to the Windows platform

repository.name: onnxruntime
repository.description: ONNX Runtime: cross-platform, high performance ML inferencing and training accelerator

issue.body:
### Discussed in https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/discussions/11765
Originally posted by **ae137** June 7, 2022 I am trying to create a custom build of onnxruntime for C++ with CUDA execution provider and install it on Windows (the encountered issue is independent of the custom build). I have built the library as described [here](https://onnxruntime.ai/docs/build/eps.html#cuda), using the tag `v1.10.0`, CUDA 11.4, CMake 3.21.1 and MSVC 19.29. Building and testing works fine. However, when I switch to `build/Windows/Release` and type `cmake --install .`, the installation folder seems to be incomplete: There is a folder `include/onnxruntime/core/providers/cpu`, but none for `cuda`. In the source directory, there is a corresponding folder `onnxruntime/core/providers`, and I wonder which of its content should end up in the installation directory? I have found a somewhat similar discussion for Linux [here](https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/issues/4725), but there are no direct equivalents for the scripts on Windows. Is it possible to bundle the installation files with CMake, or required to use Nuget?
The same issue actually arises on Linux, too, using tag `v1.10.0`, Cmake 3.22.1, g++ 11.2 and CUDA 11.4. I noticed that the nuget package for ONNX Runtime with GPU only contains `cpu_provider_factory.h` and `tensorrt_provider_factory.h`, but no `cuda_provider_factory.h` (which existed in previous versions). Regarding libraries, there is one for `_cuda` and one for `_tensorrt`, tough. Having in mind that the package is called `Microsoft.ML.OnnxRuntime.Gpu`, does this suggest that it can be used for inference on a system with GPU and CUDA, but without TensorRT?
